contentrichtext.text: {{other uses}} {{infobox UK place |official_name= Kelmscott |static_image_name= Kelmscott church, Oxfordshire.jpg |static_image_caption= St George's parish church |latitude= 51.695 |longitude= -1.638 |os_grid_reference= SU2499 |label_position= top |population= 101 |population_ref= ([[United Kingdom Census 2001|2001 census]])<ref>{{cite web |url=http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/viewFullDataset.do;jsessionid=ac1f930b30d73ec370d62b6f4444bc01a4cf1c94ffa8?instanceSelection=03070&productId=779&$ph=60_61&datasetInstanceId=3070&startColumn=1&numberOfColumns=8&containerAreaId=790500&nsjs=true&nsck=true&nssvg=true&nswid=1020 |title=Area selected: West Oxfordshire (Non-Metropolitan District) |author= |date= |work=Neighbourhood Statistics: Full Dataset View |publisher=[[Office for National Statistics]] |accessdate=29 March 2010}}</ref> |civil_parish= Kelmscott |shire_district= [[West Oxfordshire]] |shire_county= [[Oxfordshire]] |region= South East England |country= England |post_town= [[Lechlade]] |postcode_district= GL7 |postcode_area= GL |dial_code= 01367 |constituency_westminster= [[Witney (UK Parliament constituency)|Witney]] |website= [http://www.kelmscott.org.uk/ Kelmscott Village] }} '''Kelmscott''' is a village and [[Civil parishes in England|civil parish]] on the [[River Thames]] in [[West Oxfordshire]], about {{convert|2|mi|0}} east of [[Lechlade]] in neighbouring [[Gloucestershire]]. ==Parish church== The [[nave]] of the [[Church of England parish church]] of [[Saint George]] was built in about 1190 in the transitional style between [[Norman architecture|Norman]] and [[English Gothic architecture#Early English Gothic|Early English]], and the [[chancel]] is probably of the same date.<ref name=Sherwood665>{{harvnb|Sherwood|Pevsner|1974|p=665.}}</ref> The building has [[transept]]s that were added in about 1260.<ref name=Sherwood665/> The [[clerestory]] of the nave was added in the 15th century.<ref name=Sherwood665/> Many of the windows of the nave and chancel are [[English Gothic architecture#Perpendicular Gothic|Perpendicular Gothic]] additions, including the east window of the chancel.<ref name=Sherwood665/> In the churchyard is the [[tomb]] of [[William Morris]], designed by [[Philip Webb]]. Morris featured the church in his novel ''[[News from Nowhere]]'', when in the final part of the book the Guest is taken there for the feast.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} St George's parish is now part of the [[Benefice#Church of England|Benefice]] of Shill Valley and Broadshire, which includes also the parishes of [[Alvescot]], [[Black Bourton]], [[Broadwell, Oxfordshire|Broadwell]], [[Broughton Poggs]], [[Filkins]], [[Holwell, Oxfordshire|Holwell]], [[Kencot, Oxfordshire|Kencot]], [[Langford, Oxfordshire|Langford]], [[Little Faringdon]], [[Shilton, Oxfordshire|Shilton]] and [[Westwell, Oxfordshire|Westwell]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.achurchnearyou.com/benefice.php?B=27/441BF |title=Benefice of Shill Valley and Broadshire |author=[[Archbishops' Council]] |publisher=[[Church of England]] |year=2010 |accessdate=28 June 2013}}</ref> ==Kelmscott Manor== [[Kelmscott Manor]] is a [[Cotswold stone]] house, built in about 1570 during the [[Great Rebuilding]] of England and extended late in the 17th century.<ref name=Sherwood665/> It was the country home of [[William Morris]] from 1871 until his death in 1896. He drew great inspiration from the unspoilt authenticity of the house's architecture and craftsmanship, and its organic relationship with its setting.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} Kelmscott Manor now belongs to the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]].<ref>[http://www.kelmscottmanor.org.uk/ Kelmscott Manor]</ref> Morris renamed his [[London]] town house [[Kelmscott House]] after Kelmscott when he bought it in April 1879. He named his private press, which he started in 1891, [[Kelmscott Press]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources and further reading== *{{cite book |last=Fisher |first=A.S.T. |authorlink=A.S.T. Fisher |year=1968 |title=The History of Broadwell, Oxfordshire, with Filkins, Kelmscott and Holwell |location= |publisher=privately published |isbn= |ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last1=Sherwood |first1=Jennifer |last2=Pevsner |first2=Nikolaus |authorlink=Nikolaus Pevsner |year=1974 |title=Oxfordshire |series=[[Pevsner Architectural Guides#Buildings of England|The Buildings of England]] |location=Harmondsworth |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |isbn=0-14-071045-0 |pages=665â€“667 |ref=harv}} ==External links== {{Commons category inline|Kelmscott}} {{West Oxfordshire}} [[Category:Villages in Oxfordshire]] [[Category:Populated Places in Oxfordshire on the River Thames]] [[Category:West Oxfordshire]] [[Category:Civil parishes in Oxfordshire]]
